commit.message:
Explicitly allow linker version script to list not defined symbols.

This fixes compilation/linking with LLVM 17.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

iv.h.in: Fix iv_now_location_valid() prototype.

This fixes a compilation error:

error: function declaration isn’t a prototype [-Werror=strict-prototypes]

Signed-off-by: Hofi <hofione@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Balazs Scheidler <balazs.scheidler@axoflow.com>
Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

test.mt/configure.ac: Quote usage of AC_SEARCH_LIBS.

Bug: https://bugs.gentoo.org/871753
Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

iv_work: Add support for submitting work_items from within worker threads.

This patch adds iv_work_pool_submit_continuation() function that allows
the submission of work items from any of the worker threads.

The idea is to make it possible for work item handlers to decide if
some of their tasks is best carried out by a separate work item, to be
executed in parallel.

Signed-off-by: Balazs Scheidler <bazsi77@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Fix build on m68k with uclibc.

uclibc on m68k defines pthread_spinlock_t but does not define
pthread_spin_trylock, so check for this function before using it.

Fixes:
 - http://autobuild.buildroot.org/results/0a6de11c030a4f39e402917809fc6d33fb463d1b

Signed-off-by: Fabrice Fontaine <fontaine.fabrice@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

test/: Reintroduce long long printf format specifiers.

We disabled the use of %lld in commit 25815be1 ("test/: Avoid long
long printf format specifiers."), presumably due to them not being
supported on some older platforms that ivykis supports.

However, these tests all run for 5 seconds by default, which is more
than 2^32 nanoseconds, which means that we will always truncate these
fields on 32 bit platforms when printing the test results.

Some googling suggests that the %lld format specifier is part of C99,
and getting the test output right on modern 32 bit platforms seems
more important than not getting the right output on some ancient
platform that doesn't implement a 20+ year old standard -- therefore,
let's revert this change.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

iv_fd_epoll: Add support for epoll_pwait2().

The main advantage of this is high-resolution (nanosecond) timeouts.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

iv_fd: Get rid of maxfd.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

iv_fd_poll: Use a local maximum fd value, IV_FD_POLL_MAXFD.

This is the only poll method that still uses maxfd, and using a
local maximum fd in iv_fd_poll value lets us remove maxfd in a
subsequent commit.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

iv_fd_epoll: The argument to epoll_create(2) is no longer used.

Remove it (and pass in 1 instead) to prepare for the removal of maxfd.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Improve packing for struct iv_state.

Move some fields around in struct iv_state to plug some packing
holes.  This reorganization saves 16 bytes on x86_64.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Bump version number to 0.42.4.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Avoid marking pthread_atfork() as weak if provided by libc_nonshared.a.

On Linux, pthread_atfork() is provided not by libpthread.so, but by
libc_nonshared.a (for glibc >= 2.28) or by libpthread_nonshared.a
(for glibc <= 2.27), and using "#pragma weak pthread_atfork" will
cause pthread_atfork to be undefined (and have an address of NULL)
even if the relevant lib*_nonshared.a was explicitly specified to
the linker.  This is explained by this paragraph from Chapter 4,
section "Symbol Table", of the System V ABI specification, as pointed
out by Hugo Grostabussiat:

	When the link editor searches archive libraries [see ``Archive
	File'' in Chapter 7], it extracts archive members that contain
	definitions of undefined global symbols. The member's definition
	may be either a global or a weak symbol. The link editor does
	not extract archive members to resolve undefined weak symbols.
	Unresolved weak symbols have a zero value.

Therefore, if either of these lib*_nonshared.a libraries exists, we
should avoid marking pthread_atfork as weak.

We were doing this correctly for glibc <= 2.27, as we were checking
for libpthread_nonshared.a, but not for libc_nonshared.a, so we would
still mark pthread_atfork as a weak symbol on machines that provide
libc_nonshared.a but not libpthread_nonshared.a, that is, on glibc
>= 2.28 machines without a dummy backward compatibility version of
libpthread_nonshared.a installed.

This patch makes us do the right thing for glibc >= 2.28 as well, and
was derived from patches provided by Rolf Eike Beer <eike@sf-mail.de>
and Antal Nemes <antal.nemes@balabit.com>.

Thanks to Hugo Grostabussiat <bonstra@bonstra.fr.eu.org>, Henrik Grindal
Bakken <hgb@ifi.uio.no> and Tomáš Mózes <hydrapolic@gmail.com> for the
discussion and testing.

Reported-by: Changqing Li <changqing.li@windriver.com>
Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

iv_timer: Protect against some cases of timer memory corruption.

In one recent report, ivykis was getting into an infinite loop in
iv_run_timers() because of a registered iv_timer struct having
become corrupted.

Specifically, this timer was actually on the timer heap, but with a
heap index (->index) of zero, which normally indicates that the timer
is on the expired list, and ->list_expired.{next,prev} pointing to
writeable memory.  When this timer would then get to the root of the
heap, we would get into an infinite loop calling iv_timer_unregister()
on this timer, which ought to remove the timer from the heap, but in
this case wouldn't, as its heap index was already zero.

We can catch this case by making sure that whenever a timer expires
and we try to remove it from the heap, its heap index is equal to 1,
which signifies the root position, and abort if otherwise.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Bump version number to 0.42.3.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Explicitly build with -D_REENTRANT on Solaris.

Since commit 3c9bdf7a8bd2 ("Stop linking against libpthread.so by
default."), we stopped building with -pthreads on Solaris, and that
started causing this error at runtime when linked into a
multithreaded application:

	iv_fd_port_poll: got error 0[Error 0]

As László Várady explains:

	So the problem here is that after the -pthread C flag has
	been removed, ivykis started to operate on a non-threadsafe
	errno (on Solaris-like systems).  This is because -pthread
	implies -D_REENTRANT.

On Solaris, compiling a .c file without _REENTRANT and without
_POSIX_C_SOURCE set to some value >= 199506 will cause 'errno' to refer
to the main (first) thread's errno variable, instead of to the errno
variable for the thread we are running in.  From /usr/include/errno.h
on a Solaris 11 machine:

	#if defined(_REENTRANT) || defined(_TS_ERRNO) || _POSIX_C_SOURCE - 0 >= 199506L
	extern int *___errno();
	#define errno (*(___errno()))
	#else
	extern int errno;
	#endif

The reason for not unconditionally implementing errno with a function
call is presumably performance, as it will be slightly slower to access
errno by dereferencing the return value of a function call than by
accessing a bss variable directly, but for ivykis it's fine to always
go via the function call, as we don't access errno very often, and the
alternative would be to build ivykis twice, once with _REENTRANT and
once without, and then to deal with the complexity of picking the right
one to use, which sounds like it has potential for yet more screwups,
and which doesn't seem worth it.

Fixes: 3c9bdf7a8bd2 ("Stop linking against libpthread.so by default.")
Reported-by: Brian De Wolf (github: bldewolf)
Reported-by: Filip Hajny (github: mamash)
Tested-by: László Várady <laszlo.varady@balabit.com>
Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Don't install IV_FD_PUMP_INIT.3 when on a case sensitive filesystem.

This fixes the following build error on platforms that use case
sensitive filesystems:

	make: *** No rule to make target `IV_FD_PUMP_INIT.3', needed by `all-am'.  Stop.

Reported-by: Gergely Nagy <algernon@madhouse-project.org>
Reported-by: Gergő Nagy <gergo.nagy@balabit.com>
Reported-by: Orion Poplawski <orion@nwra.com>
Reported-by: László Várady <laszlo.varady@balabit.com>
Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Bump version number to 0.42.2.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

iv_event: Hold a reference on the main loop for each registered iv_event.

Since commit 78c0a307e049 ("iv_event: Optimize away creation of
iv_event_raw in single-threaded apps."), registering an iv_event object
in a single-threaded application does not cause the reference count for
the ivykis main loop to be bumped anymore, which will make iv_main()
return even when there are iv_event objects registered.  Fix this by
bumping the reference count on the main loop by hand for each iv_event
that is registered.

Fixes: 78c0a307e049 ("iv_event: Optimize away creation of iv_event_raw in single-threaded apps.")
Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Add a test case for the __iv_event_run_pending_events() crash bug.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

iv_event: Fix crash in __iv_event_run_pending_events().

Commit 09857826675c ("iv_event: Optimize out one mutex lock/unlock pair
per event delivery iteration.") tried to optimize out a lock by caching
the `iv_list_empty` operation.  It is possible to remove item from the
list while `ie->handler(ie->cookie)` runs, which could invalidate the
value of the cached `empty_now` variable.  If no item left on the list,
it should stop the loop, but it cached continue causing undefined behavior.

Reported-by: Antal Nemes <antal.nemes@balabit.com>
Fixes: 09857826675c ("iv_event: Optimize out one mutex lock/unlock pair per event delivery iteration.")
Signed-off-by: kokan <peter.kokai@balabit.com>
Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Bump version number to 0.42.1.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Fix segfault when calling IV_TASK_INIT() before iv_init().

We don't guarantee that IV_TASK_INIT() can safely be called before
iv_init(), and the iv_init.3 man page actually says the following:

	Each thread that wants to use ivykis must call iv_init before
	any other ivykis functions are called.

Regardless, calling IV_TASK_INIT() before iv_init() used to work okay
before commit 30a281489a5b ("iv_task: Allow task registered by another
task to run immediately."), and, depending on how you look at it, this
commit could be considered to have caused a regression.

This patch fixes IV_TASK_INIT() so that it won't crash if it is called
before iv_init(), by using a task epoch value of zero in case we are
called from a thread that has no attached ivykis event loop.

Fixes: 30a281489a5b ("iv_task: Allow task registered by another task to run immediately.")
Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Fix object reference counting bug when unregistering an expired timer.

If two timers expire during the same poll epoch, and the timer whose
handler happens to run first unregisters the other timer, we would
accidentally decrement the count of objects registered to the current
thread's ivykis event loop, st->numobjs, one too many times.

This could cause the object count to drop to zero, and iv_main() to
return while there are still objects registered, or it could cause the
object count to go negative, and iv_main() to not return even though
it should.

This patch fixes the logic in iv_timer_unregister() to only decrement
st->numobjs if the timer we are unregistering was on the timer heap,
and to avoid decrementing if the timer is on the list of expired
timers, and that fixes this bug.  And while we're at it, let's add a
test case to catch this bug.

Fixes: 7190532aca90 ("iv_timer: Implement fairness for timers.")
Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Bump version number to 0.42.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Add a test case for the "timer expiry at time zero" bug.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Fix ->set_poll_timeout() related bug with timers that expire at time zero.

If the ivykis core decides to use ->set_poll_timeout() to offload the
handling of a timer, the epoll_create(2) / port_create(3C) poll
methods pass the given timeout directly into the timerfd_settime(2) /
timer_settime(3C) system calls, but if an ivykis user has registered
an iv_timer with an expiration time of (tv_sec, tv_nsec) = (0, 0),
the *_settime() system calls will interpret such a zero timeout value
as a request to disable the timer, and as a result, no timer handlers
will be run.

To work around this, we'll pass a timeout of (tv_sec, tv_nsec) = (0, 1)
into these system calls if the next expiring timer expires at (0, 0).

This bug was reported by and tracked down with the kind help of
Brian De Wolf (github: bldewolf), who ran into this issue with
syslog-ng 3.9.1.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Bump version number to 0.41.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

test/: Use iv_get_thread_id().

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>

Stop linking against libpthread.so by default.

Signed-off-by: Lennert Buytenhek <buytenh@wantstofly.org>
